item.title: Composing (making music for actual instruments to play)
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
DHO:

Been studying classical composition and hoping to get deeper into jazz soon.

That’s awesome! I should take a break from Auxy one of these days and work on classical music again. It’s just so much work to compose for classical instruments the way I do it xD

item.title: Composing (making music for actual instruments to play)
item.dc:creator: wagneric
item.description:
Noteflight is definitely fiddly, but useful; I composed some piano trio pieces with it. Musescore is another good one – like Finale or Sibelius but plays nicer with Auxy’s midi out (and free). I’ve used Auxy to write snippets for pipe organ, recently.

Read full topic

item.title: Composing (making music for actual instruments to play)
item.dc:creator: Sunny
item.description:
Have a look into noteflight as well. You can write orchestral pieces on sheet music, and you can play it and it almost sounds as good as the real thing.

The website is a bit fiddly, but certainly worth a gander.

Read full topic

item.title: Composing (making music for actual instruments to play)
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
I’ve done huge amounts of regular composition work. One of them was a collection of seven preludes that were modal in nature.

dropbox.com

Modal%20I-VII.pdf

The way that they were written was to make sure audio played back the way I wanted it to, so some of it may not be completely possible because of that (namely the last bar of track #5), but the audio playback is here

https://www.dropbox.com/s/mnyenr4zkcoxjgw/Modal%20I-VII.wav?dl=0

(dropbox links don’t tend to work if it’s the audio on this forum, something I’ve found)

I’ve also done orchestral arrangements of pieces before, along with other pieces of that nature, on my actual SoundCloud.
https://soundcloud.com/james-lucien-official/sets/orchestral-works

Read full topic
